1.1.section: 1. Data description and collection or re-use of existing data
1.1.question: How will new data be collected or produced and/or how will existing data be re-used?
paragraphs: As part of the project, experimental data will be collected in multiple formats, including videos, photographs, CBCT
images and written reports. Additionally, testing machines will record numerical data such as force, displacement, and
time. Information about cadavers (age, sex, height and weight) and detailed characteristics of individual samples
(tissue type, material condition, dimensions) will be gathered and organized in tabular form. The project will also
incorporate existing data obtained during preliminary studies. These datasets will be reviewed, selected, and
restructured to comply with the newly adopted methodology.

1.2.section: 1. Data description and collection or re-use of existing data
1.2.question: What data (for example the types, formats, and volumes) will be collected or produced?
paragraphs: Databases will be stored in Excel format (.xlsx) and as comma-separated values (.csv), with a maximum size of 1 GB per
file. Experimental results will be saved in digital formats, including video (AVI, MTS, MP4), images (CR2, JPG, PNG), and
text documents (PDF, DOCX, TXT), with a total size of up to 40 GB. Additionally, raw data will be preserved in
proprietary file extensions generated by Catman’s Data Acquisition Software. Data related to numerical models will be
stored in formats specific to Abaqus (odb files). The size of results from a single simulation is expected to range from 5
GB to 50 GB. Overall, the estimated volume of newly generated data will not exceed 10 TB.

2.1.question: What metadata and documentation (for example methodology or data collection and way of organising data) will accompany data?
paragraphs: danym
The organization of data will be documented by the research team, including a standardized naming convention for
directories and files. Each cadaver used in the experiments will be assigned a unique identifier. Metadata for
biomechanical tests will include cadaver details (age, sex, weight and height), a shorthand name for the ligament, and
the Functional Spinal Unit number from which the ligament was sourced. Metadata for numerical simulations will
contain the calculation date and a unique code describing all necessary identification parameters.
Selected datasets will be managed using the MOST Wiedzy Open Research Data Catalog, which supports Persistent
Identifiers (PIDs) and complies with widely adopted standards such as DataCite. Metadata will be stored in JSON-LD
format to ensure interoperability and accessibility. Additionally, each dataset will include a README.txt file providing
usage instructions and explanations of abbreviations or domain-specific terminology.

2.2.question: What data quality control measures will be used?
paragraphs: Data quality will be ensured through rigorous validation and standardized protocols. All data will be collected,
processed, and verified by at least two trained team members, who will receive dedicated instruction on measurement
instruments, data acquisition methodologies, and quality assurance procedures. A double-check protocol will be
applied, requiring independent verification of critical data and metadata by two team members.
Certified, high-precision measurement instruments, including testing machines, optical fiber sensors, and cameras, will
be used, with regular maintenance performed according to manufacturer guidelines. A version control system will be
implemented to maintain data integrity, track changes, and prevent loss or overwriting. All datasets will include
comprehensive documentation, with metadata structured according to tidy data principles. These measures will
minimize errors and ensure consistency, reliability, and reproducibility throughout the project.

3.1.section: 3. Storage and backup during the research process
3.1.question: How will data and metadata be stored and backed up during the research process?
paragraphs: Data obtained during the tests and accompanying metadata will be stored on a secure personal computer, with two
backup copies created monthly and synchronized with the department’s cloud storage. Additional backup copies will
be maintained on password-protected external hard drives available in the department, managed by the Principal
Investigator and Investigator 1.
Project documentation, manuscript drafts, and interim reports will be stored on Microsoft OneDrive (Office 365 A1
faculty license) and on Overleaf servers, where backup procedures are handled by the respective service providers.

3.2.section: 3. Storage and backup during the research process
3.2.question: How will data security and protection of sensitive data be taken care of during the research?
paragraphs: Sensitive data will not be processed within the project. However, data security will be ensured through multiple
measures. The computer used for data storage will have its password changed every three months, and backup
services will follow their respective security protocols. Remote access to project computers from outside the university
network will only be possible via an authorized VPN connection provided and managed by the University’s IT Section.

4.1.question: If personal data are processed, how will compliance with legislation on personal data and on data security be ensured?
paragraphs: przetwarzania danych osobowych
No personal data will be processed in the project. Data related to cadavers will be collected anonymously, with
information strictly limited to gender, age, weight, and height.

4.2.question: How will other legal issues, such as intelectual property rights and ownership, be managed? What legislation is applicable?
paragraphs: przepisy
The ownership and management of all intellectual property created through collaboration within the Project shall
remain with Gdańsk University of Technology, in accordance with Polish law and institutional regulations (Resolution of
the Senate of Gdańsk University of Technology No. 117/2021/XXV of 19 May 2021).
Research data and results will be made available under an open-access model, following Plan S requirements, and
licensed under one of the Creative Commons licenses. Data deposited in open research repositories will carry either a
CC-BY or CC-0 license. Metadata descriptions for these datasets will always be freely accessible under CC-0, without
any restrictions. No embargo or other limitations will apply.

5.1.question: How and when will data be shared? Are there possible restrictions to data sharing or embargo reasons?
paragraphs: The data will be disseminated partly through the open research data repository (MOST WIEDZY) and partly via open-
access scientific journal platforms. When required by the publisher, raw data will be made available at the time of
publication.

access scientific journal platforms. When required by the publisher, raw data will be made available at the time of

tagged_paragraphs.text: publication.

5.2.question: How will data for preservation be selected, and where will data be preserved long-term (for example a data repository or archive)?
paragraphs: repozytorium lub archiwum danych)
All data necessary to substantiate the conclusions drawn during the Project will be selected for preservation. In
addition, any data with potential for future reuse will also be retained to ensure completeness. These datasets will be
prepared in accordance with the FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) and stored for a
minimum of 10 years at the Centre of Informatics – Tricity Academic Supercomputer and Network (CI TASK), as well as
on additional external drives available within the department. Data deposited in the MOST Wiedzy repository will be
automatically classified for long-term storage with no expiration date.

5.3.question: What methods or software tools will be needed to access and use the data?
paragraphs: Some of the data will be stored in standard formats, making them accessible with publicly available software. Data
generated from numerical simulations in Abaqus will be saved in formats such as .odb (output database) and .inp
(input file), which require Abaqus/CAE or Abaqus Viewer for access. Currently, Abaqus Viewer is available under
appropriate licensing.

generated from numerical simulations in Abaqus will be saved in formats such as .odb (output database) and .inp

5.4.question: How will the application of a unique and persistent identifier (such us a Digital Object Identifier (DOI)) to each data set be ensured?
paragraphs: każdego zestawu danych
In the MOST Wiedzy repository, all deposited datasets will be assigned unique DOI identifiers to ensure persistent and
reliable referencing.

6.1.question: Who (for example role, position, and institution) will be responsible for data management (i.e the data steward)?
paragraphs: The Principal Investigator (PI) will be responsible for all aspects of data management, including planning,
implementation, quality assurance, and compliance with institutional requirements. Co-Investigators will assist with
specific tasks such as data storage, external backups, and metadata preparation.
Gdańsk University of Technology supports the PI through units such as the Open Science Competence Center, which
provides guidance on creating and versioning Data Management Plans (DMPs), ensures metadata quality and
completeness in the repository, and assists repository users. CI TASK and CUI maintain the infrastructure for data
archiving, while the IT Service Center oversees repository development and provides technical support. University
regulations introduced by the Rector promote open science practices. Additionally, Data Stewards offer faculty-level
support within relevant scientific disciplines.
